reviewText: ...I've got to agree with some of the other reviewers re: over-use of the horn section. It would be fine if they were used occasionally, but just because you have a horn section onstage doesn't mean you have to use it ON EVERY SONG. That being said, the video quality, sound and performances are excellent - especially the vocals.

reviewText: Don't get me wrong. The Doobies have shown from the very beginning that they can play, put on a great show and improve your mood just by hearing them. One reviewer described the show (paraphrasing) as a relief not to endure the "insufferable, castrated vocals of Michael McDonald". Let me clue you in, Mac. For as much as Tommy Johnston should be credited for the Doobies' sound, so should Michael. That said, the Doobies are one of the few surviving Rock bands to maintain their integrity and not become a complete shadow of their former selves. I happen to feel that a void was left when Michael departed.

reviewText: Great songs, wonderful musical talent, outstanding visual quality (watch this in Hi-Def for unbelievable clarity), terrific interaction with the crowd, and interesting DVD extras.  The Doobies July, 2004, concert at Virginia's Wolf Trap has it all!The Doobies have always been my favorite band and I have everything they're ever done, but I was blown away by this great DVD. This concert is far superior to the other Doobie DVD, "Rockin' Down the Highway - The Wildlife Concert". Renditions of old Doobie favorites are terrific and the musical talent that these men have glows prominently.  Versatile John McFee demonstrates his range by playing about 5 different guitar types ranging from pedal steel to acoustic.  He's great on the fiddle as well!  Pat Simmons and Tom Johnston show their musical range as well and sound better than ever on every song!  Bass player Skylark carries the rhythm and energy of this concert.  Drummers Keith Knudson and Mike Hossack provide the depth and beat that they're long known for.  And the addition of the horn section, led by saxophonist Marc Russo, adds new punch to the favorite songs that Doobie fans know so well!Clocking in at a minute over two hours, the Brothers entertain the crowd the entire time with absolutely no downtime.  Twenty-plus favorites from the past are offered by the Doobs on this great DVD.  "Don't Start Me Talkin", "Little Bitty Pretty One", and staples like "Listen To the Music", "China Grove", and "Long Train Runnin" carry the freight during the concert, but the listener won't be disappointed with any song!If you're a fan of the Doobie Brothers, you absolutely have to add "Live At the Wolf Trap" to your musical collection!
summary: Hard to find anything you won't like as the Doobies rock Wolf Trap

reviewText: Very rarely does a concert keep you on the edge of your seat for the entire set, but this delivers one fantastic track after another until the very end. Before watching this DVD i was familiar mainly with the hits, only what was played on the radio: China Grove, Listen to the music, Jesus is just alright etc... The exciting, electrifying versions of these songs impressed me no end, but what really blew me away were the songs I wasn't familiar with, some of the guitar work in the middle acoustic set was absolutely incredible, and each song gave even more great guitar work whilst always varying the style of music they were playing. The combination of the great songs, the great band, the great sound (dts) makes this a must have for any Doobie fan or basically any fan of great music.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I do agree with many reviewers who said that this is an excellent concert DVD by the Doobie Brothers, except for the over-use of horns. Why would you supplant guitars for saxaphones? "South City Midnight Lady" (an excellent song) sounded really bizarre with it's use of steel guitar and saxaphone. Maybe it's just me, but I've never been a fan of the sax and think it has ruined many a good song. And to hear the sax and the steel used in the same song is..well it's just wrong. Over all, this is an excellent DVD. The sound and camera use is great, and the band (a rather large band) is in top form. The Doobie's versatility has never failed to amaze me, and this concert has it in spades. Lap steel, electric guitar, acoustic guitar, pedal steel,fiddle, it's all there, and done very well. To see Pat Simmons jumping around like a man half his age is wonderful to behold. All in all, this is a very, very good dvd of a very good concert, performed by an excellent band. Get this, enjoy it, share with a sceptical friend.

reviewText: This was filmed on July 25, 2004, at the Wolf Trap National Park, For The Performing Arts. It's a great concert, that includes all their classics. Even though they are not from the south, they do sing many songs with southern themes, like "Old Black Water", "China Grove", "Rainy Day Crossroad Blues", "South City Midnight Lady", an others. I also like their other classics, such as "Taking it to the Streets", "Listen to the Music", and "Long Train Running" and many others. All these classic songs, mentioned, are included in this great concert. I love the Doobie Brothers, and I highly recommend this concert dvd. Thanks!!!
summary: An Outstanding 23 Song Concert, By The Legendary Doobie Brothers Band = A1+!!!

reviewText: After watching the Wolf Trap Live DVD for the 14th time, I still can't get enough of it!  This concert includes 23 songs and is beautifully mastered in both sound and cinematography.  It is without a doubt, the Doobie Brothers' finest performance ever.  In one of the special feature interviews, Tom Johnston states, "we practice alot these days."  Well, Mr. Johnston, it shows.  Every song is played tightly and precisely yet mingled with an easiness and playfulness that can only come from professionals who have honed their craft to perfection.  The Doobie Brothers were awesome in the 70's but in my opinion, have only recently reached the pinacle of music success with this DVD.  Other 70's bands seem to have declined through the years but, not the Doobies.  They have aged like fine wine. Take my advise and beat the winter blues: make this DVD part of your collection as soon as possible.  You have no idea what you are missing out on until you experience it.
summary: Wolf Trap Live: Best Entertainment Value For Your Money

reviewText: In the 70's, I only heard a handful of Doobie Brothers songs.  I liked "Long Train Runnin'" (in spite of the fact that in gym class, I heard it 5 times daily for a month while the girls' P.E. class learned pom pom routines to it).  I was not as much of a fan of the other songs I knew were by them, that is, "Black Water" and "It Keeps You Running" (which is not on this project).Let's jump ahead close to twenty years later.  I heard a song by DC Talk called "Jesus Is Just Alright By Me", and loved it.  Then, I discovered the Doobies were the original artists.  I didn't really like the original as much as the remake, and I filed that in another reason I wasn't a Doobie fan.  (I still wonder if that song originally was a profession of faith in Christ or just a comment that Jesus loves everyone and don't judge me by what I do.)Another decade plus later, I heard "China Grove", "Taking It To The Street", and "Listen To The Music", and starting liking them better.  (I also changed my mind on "Black Water".)  As a result, I checked out this DVD.  I watched the whole concert and the interviews.  I'm now a Doobie fan.One thing that positively impressed me is that this band both enjoyed playing and seemed to enjoy working together.  In the interviews, they mentioned they work as a democracy, and it shows.  They also shared the joy to the audience:  I loved the audience participation encouraged on "Black Water", "Long Train Runnin'", and "Listen To The Music".  Another is the eclectic influences; there were individual songs that could be called soul, country, blues, and rock.  I enjoy this unique sound.Let me compare the teamwork with a couple of other videos I saw.  Talking Heads is technically a four person band, and on "Stop Making Sense" had an additional fivesome, but it clearly came across as David Byrne and his back-up.  With the Doobies, Pat and Tom dominated the talking but they definitely shared the wealth.  Also, I saw a Neil Diamond video recently, in which Neil didn't introduce the band (except for the female background singer, and that was because they did a duet), and the band was listed at the end of the credits after everything else.  With the Doobies, the band was the first one listed.  (One side note:  Though the music is different, and though what I said above is better pictured by the Doobies, the Go Go's live concert available on VHS and DVD captures the same joy and team spirit, though drummer Gina Shock didn't seem happy in it.)
summary: Not A Doobie Fan In The '70's; That's No Longer True

reviewText: I was totally blown away with this concert!  The guys put on one hell of a great show.  I was so glad to find that they are not only still touring, but also still making great new music.  To me, it doesn't matter what sound they had.  I know that members have come and gone throughout the years (as Tom Johnston and Pat Simmons stated) but the guys still have it.  I too was wondering about why Michael MacDonald wasn't featured here.  One thing I'm sick of hearing from people who claim to be "dedicated fans" of the group is that they hated the music they did with Michael MacDonald.  Yes the sound was a little different, but Michael got the band to win a Grammy.  I was also wondering what happened to bassist Tiran Porter.  But I saw Skylark's ambition and was floored.  The band is great, and so is the music.  Check it out.P.S.  Listen to what they had to say on how they became a band.  Interesting story!
summary: Awesome concert from an awesome band!

reviewText: This and The Eagles - Farewell I Tour are my absolute favorite concert DVDs. The Doobie Brothers are top notch. When they start out with two guitars hanging around their necks you can pretty much figure on some real guitar playin!  The DTS 5.1 surround sound makes you feel like you are right in the audience.  This is a really fun DVD to watch and listen to.  The audience is appreciative but quiet enough that they don't distract from the show.  This is one purchase you won't regret.

reviewText: Although I've seen the Doobie Brothers live at two different concerts, I wouldn't say I was their best fan.  I like about ten of their songs and this DVD has 23.  The first time I watch a DVD I look at the whole thing.  Later I skip to the parts I like the best.  Even being unfamiliar with some of the songs, I had to note that the band was rocking and so were the fans in the audience.  The music sounded great, the band was working hard, they all looked teriffic and the setting was perfect.  What more could you ask for?  They sure haven't lost their magical touch - or their voices or playing ability for that matter.  I would highly recommend this DVD, especially if you are a Doobie Brothers fan.
summary: A Wonderful Performance at Wolf Trap

reviewText: the doobies actually had two lives, one with johnson on vocals, and one with mcdonald on vocals with the latter bringing a more smoother jazz sound to the band, this dvd is all johnson,though it was nice to hear ''another park, another sunday'' i feel this tour featured too much horn playing and an over orchestated sound, when i heard my favorite song '' long train runnin' i was dissappointed by the subtle electric guitar playing and the sax taking over the harmonica lead, i now wish i would have opted for ''rockin' down the highway'' dvd which offered a more true version of their past though this one is still worth buying

reviewText: I bought this DVD on a whim.Searching for concert DVD's I came across this-checked the reviews and got an idea of the song listings-thought about it-ordered it.I wasted approx. 1 hour debating the undebatable.I never thought twice about purchasing tickets for a Doobie show when they were in my area before(always a favorite and never the same twice).Any fan of the Doobies (or 70s rock can order this without any second guessing-it is "A MAJOR HOME RUN".Tom and Pat's musicianship are never better.Jeff McFee is a monster on all the instruments he plays.Tiran Porter is missed(original bassist) however, Skylark on bass is more than a replacement-he IS a Doobie.Big John Hartman is also missed(original member on drums)but Keith Knudsen and Michael Hossack are still there and Tight.A percussion and horn section(new Doobies?)is as good as I have heard.As stated earlier the musicianship is never better-so are the harmonies.They will put cold chills down your arm.So you can buy this DVD in confidence off the bat and get your HOME RUN.Gotta go-"Clear as the Driven Snow" is playing.

reviewText: But not without a few disappointments. Gone is the delightful menu presented by the band members on the original DVD, and I couldn't access the five icons in the lower left corner during certain songs which on the original DVD would take you briefly behind the scenes to see how the writers were inspired. So if you still have your DVD of this concert, it might be worth hanging on to. Nevertheless, if it's just about the concert (and it mainly is as far as I'm concerned), this blu ray really brings out the clarity of those high definition cameras you probably noticed on the DVD, so this is still a worthy upgrade. Tom Johnston admits they never sounded this good way back when, as I too would attest, after seeing their poor performance in Frankfort Kentucky during their "Vices" tour in the 70's.To the dismay of some fans (and the delight of others), this concert is more or less a representation of their pre-Michael McDonald years with a couple or so exceptions, such as "Takin' It To The Streets", voiced very nicely by Simmons in his stead. The infinitely versatile McFee is a valuable asset to this lineup (Hossack and Knudsen have since passed away so it's nice to have this to remember them by). At least the half hour documentary remains intact, so you're not missing much from the original DVD here. A more comprehensive history that includes the very talented Michael McDonald can be found on the other blu ray that is now out (Let The Music Play). Yes, the MM years were good years too and I still treasure many of those songs as well. This show however is the way they sounded at the beginning, so "listen to the music". That's their legacy, and as far as I'm concerned, they made history that night at Wolf Trap.If you like the band and their music, this will be among your favorite concert videos. I have always found myself smiling all the way through this thing, honest.
Title: N/A
